item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
As Luisa Castellani will retire after the summer, Luis and Luisa have already started working in tandem for the last few months and will continue to do so until Luisa retires.

I would of course like to seize this opportunity to already sincerely thank Luisa wholeheartedly for her excellent work and personal commitment in this crucial role as "bridge builder" between SCIC's management and the Interpreters Delegation and congratulate her –a bit in advance - for a long and exemplary career in DG Interpretation.

I have no doubt that Luis Machado will also be a trusted interlocutor for the DI and that he will bring a positive contribution to social dialogue in DG Interpretation.

Florika Fink-Hooijer

item.title: Top Ten Tablet Tips for Interpreters
item.description: More and more interpreters are using tablets in the booth. Here are tips* on some of the built-in features and apps that are most useful to us in the booth, first some basics, and then more specifically for interpretation purposes:
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
Organising your tablet

  • Tip 1: Organise your apps by pressing and then holding on an icon, then drag it across another to create a folder containing those two apps. The folder can be named appropriately, and more icons added to it, making it easier to keep track of various apps and links.
     
  • Tip 2: If you want to add a direct link to a certain web page to your tablet, click on (the box/upward arrow symbol) in the Safari browser and then select 'Add to home screen', which will create an icon for that page, which can then be saved in a folder as described above.


Working efficiently with a tablet

  • Tip 3: Screenshots are taken by pressing the home and off buttons simultaneously.
     
  • Tip 4: Multitasking is enabled by double tapping the home button, which will enable you to move between the various apps you have open.
     
  • Tip 5: Pressing on (the box/upward arrow symbol) gives you the option to AirDrop a web page to anyone within short range who also has a tablet with this functionality enabled – perfect for sharing interesting material between colleagues.
     
  • Tip 6:  At any time when on the internet, if you press and hold on a word, the option to look up the definition of that particular term will appear.


Useful apps

  • Tip 7: Never print a document that needs signing again. Sign Now (which – like all apps - can be found in the App store) lets you introduce your signature on online forms without putting pen to paper.
     
  • Tip 8. Scanning applications such as ScanBot can be used for scanning important papers like travel documents and medical bills, making administrative tasks a lot more efficient. This app also comes with OCR (Optical Character Recognition), which means it will (in theory) be able to make sense of your handwriting as well. Good if you want to integrate handwritten glossaries in such apps as
     
  • Tip 9: AirTable, GoodReader or TapForms - highly useful for working with PDF documents, annotating them, and creating glossaries with search functions like those used in databases. If you are more of an Excel person there are apps that will accommodate your tastes too, such as Excel for iPad, Numbers, Google Sheets.
     
  • Tip 10: Podcasts. To millennials what the wireless was to their great-grandparents. There is a never ending supply of podcasts covering any topic you care to mention. Great for learning/maintaining languages, not least because of the speed function, which enables you to slow down speakers so you can make sense of what they're saying (Can we have this in the booth, please?!).


    And finally
  • Tip 11: (Bonus tip!) If you want to take your tablet use to the next level, there is something called the Apple Pencil (why they didn't call it iPen, I don’t know. It should have iPenned.) that you can use to take consec notes directly on your screen. The more things change, the more they stay the same…

 

*(Piously pilfered from the recent webinar hosted by A. Drechsel et al)

item.title: Du football, de la joie ...
item.description: et du bonheur pour le gagnant du SCIC au gros lot de la tombola!
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
Le weekend dernier a eu lieu la 21ème édition du Schuman Trophy et le SCIC était présent avec une équipe hors du commun comme vous pouvez le voir sur la photo. 3 vaillantes filles (merci Arianna, Jamila et Liene) sont venues renforcer l'équipe et ont apporté la bonne humeur, le charme, la grâce et surtout beaucoup de discipline féminine.


Nous avons débuté sur un score de 1-0, victoire méritée contre ECFIN. Ensuite  nous avons rencontré nos cousins de la Traduction qui, pour la première fois depuis plusieurs années, nous ont battu 2-0. La condition physique laissait quelque peu à désirer. Il faisait très chaud samedi dernier et, étant donné qu'il fallait bien s'hydrater, quelqu'un a un peu exagéré avec la bière. Nous n'avons cependant pas baissé les bras et nous avons continué à nous battre sur le terrain dans un esprit sportif et convivial. Nous avons fait match nul contre DEVCO (1-1) et contre BUDG (0-0). Résultat final: 5 points sur 4 matches. Pas si mal que ça compte tenu du fait que la plupart des joueurs er joueuses n'avaient jamais joué ensemble auparavant.

Mais ce qui compte vraiment c'est que les vrais vainqueurs du tournoi sont les enfants défavorisés que le Comité du Schuman Trophy soutient depuis toujours.

Et il y a aussi un autre gagnant: quelqu'un parmi vous a gagné le gros lot à la tombola Schuman Trophy. Le premier prix consiste en un iMac, iPad et iPhone. A vos billets (si vous en avez achetés bien entendu)!!! Et contrôlez si vous êtes parmi les heureux gagnants en suivant le lien.......

Allez le SCIC!!!

 

---

item.title: UPDATE: EU Open Day a great success!
item.description: We invite you to read the report on the Open Doors Day, summarising in detail actions taken as well as showing feedback from colleagues.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
The report is avaliable here.


12/05:
Many SCIC colleagues in the Berlaymont and Europa buildings contributed to the success of this year's Open Day.

The EU institutions in Brussels opened their doors on 6 May to celebrate Europe Day. It is a once a year opportunity for citizens, along with staff and their families to visit all the EU institutions.

In the Schuman room in Berlaymont, SCIC organised and delivered a non-stop programme of 15 presentations and debates from a number of DGs, animated by Head of Communication Miklós Mátyássy. But also SCIC with Florika Fink-Hooijer, Maria Grazia Coletta, Anabela Frade and José Iturri, as well as the trainees Sarah Bedson, Ioanna Pilavaki, Mikel Igartua Querejeta and Walker Darke shared their knowledge and experience. José Iturri was featured in a radio interview.

This was accompanied by interpretation in 4 languages, as well as the opportunity to try out being an interpreter with the assistance of SCIC interpreters. People of all ages took part in the programme, and all left having learnt something new – young people being inspired by interpreters to learn languages or learning about the European Commission and the EU's policies, with popular presentations being on prevention of radicalisation, Erasmus +, the EU Budget and many more.

In the Europa building, SCIC had a large presence where staff presented the basics of interpreting to guided tour groups as well as taking questions on getting 'lost in translation', 'English after Brexit',  and 'What's the funniest thing you ever heard?' – you'll have to ask them for their answer! Our colleague Jacqueline Veltman was featured in a Belgian television report.

SCIC would like to give it's thanks to all the volunteers who made this fantastic event possible.

Director-General Florika Fink-Hooijer praised the work of SCIC staff:

'I'd like to reiterate it herewith to all who participated for DG SCIC at the Open Doors Day. A big thank you for setting up throughout the entire Saturday a very impressive citizens' dialogue while also showcasing the many talents and services our DG offers!'

According to speaker José Iturri: 'Everything was very well organised, and I really enjoyed it!'

Interpreter Brendan Woods, who was guiding visitors in the Europa building, declared:

'As always, having seen the architecture and having had the decision making process explained to them, our visitors were delighted to encounter the human side of it all.

SCIC interpreters explained the basics of what we do and then our visitors had a chance to ask questions. The groups are always impressed by what we do and I think it's a great outreach opportunity because many people know very little about the EU and seeing a kind and enthusiastic volunteer talk about their daily work really does put a face to the notorious "Faceless Eurocrat".'

Chiara Colucci was welcoming visitors in the Schuman room and concluded:

'Personally, it is one of those occasions – rare, I must say, for people working behind the scenes like me – to tell people what I do, why I do it and why I am proud of being part of it. It is the kind of events when you get the chance to talk directly and informally to the public, not behind a computer screen, and I think they particularly like the fact that they can 'touch' us, that they can go in the booth and see that interpreters are real!'

SCIC played a part in promoting the Open Day across social media, with a sample showing that in partnership with other DG's, people viewed the hashtag #EUOpenDay more than 1.7 million times on Twitter.

Have a look at the photos taken of SCIC colleagues in the Schuman room (Part 1 - Part 2 - Part 3) and the Europa building.

More photos of the event: the Berlaymont building and the Europa building.

 

You can watch the different sessions via the following links of webstreaming: 

  • Mini citizens' dialogue for the opening of Open Doors Day (Commissioner Günther Oettinger, Florika Fink-Hooijer)

  • Interpretation and Multilingualism (Maria Grazia Coletta and Anabela Frade, DG Interpretation)

  • Prevention of radicalisation (DG Migration & Home Affairs)

  • Mini-citizens’ dialogue “The European Social Fund – 60 years of investing in people” (DG Employment, Social Affairs & Inclusion)

  • 60 years of the Treaty of Rome and the future of the EU

  • Mini citizens’ dialogue “From Erasmus to Erasmus+: A story of 30 years” (Commissioner Carlos Moedas)

  • Mini citizens’ dialogue “Regions matter: How does the EU help create jobs and growth in its regions?” (DG Regional and Urban Policy)

  • Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions: 20 years supporting excellent researchers. What are you waiting for?  (DG Education, Youth Sport & Culture)

  • 15 years of the Euro  

  • Copernicus for  Citizens, the EU's satellite programme (DG Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs)

  • Trainees at European Commission (Sarah Bedson, Walker Darke, Mikel Igartua Querejeta and Ioanna Pilavaki, DG Interpretation)

  • Anniversaries of LIFE programme,Ecolabel and Natura 2000  (DG Environment)

  • ITER and fusion: Towards a new source of energy (DG Energy)

  • Parler en public, cela fait peur! (José Iturri, DG Interpretation)

  • Future of the EU budget (Nadia Calviño, DG Budget)

  • Closing (Miklós Mátyássy, DG Interpretation)
     


Martina André-Kaut & Karla Hanzlová
Communication Sector

item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
Safety and security are of paramount importance in every day work in the EU institutions. It is the responsibility of the EU institutions to ensure appropriate structures and procedures to be deployed in emergency situations. It is also a duty of each member of staff to know how to react in a critical situation such as a fire, cyber or terrorist attack.

The tragic events of March 2016 showed that we need to be prepared for a potential terrorist threat. You might find it interesting to hear about specialised training offered to DG SCIC staff travelling on mission to exotic third countries. At any time and place, it might be useful to know the basic principles of First Aid.

The Safety and Security Week on 26-30 June 2017 offers DG SCIC staff a series of lunch time sessions covering a range of safety and security related topics, including First Aid, Cyber Security, Security in the Council and much more.

item.title: Watch: How to use tablets in the booth
item.description: SCIC News caught up with Fernando Leitao, to find out more about the recent webinar.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
SCIC hosted a webinar session on the use of documents and tablets in the booth for interpreters.

'It's becoming essential to use a tablet because it saves time, makes it easier to manage your documents, and most of all more efficient! In this webinar, you'll find out some things you didn't know your tablet could do, as well as some other interesting practical clues for simultaneous interpreters.' said Fernando Leitao.

In cooperation with the International Annual Meeting on Language Arrangements, Documentation and Publications (IAMLADP), which is the organisation that unites all the languages services at international institutions such as the European Commission, European Parliament, and the United Nations, the webinar was a joint training venture with the E-learning taskforce.

This training has been available as a face-to-face module for interpreters, and has been available for young student interpreters as part of their virtual classes with SCIC, but this is available to all on the European Commission Website.

This was also the first time it was hosted by the European Commission. Simone Howse and Philippe Demay from the European Parliament, alongside SCIC interpreter Alexander Drechsel, taught the course, with Fernando Leitao and Alexandra Panagakou presenting.

So far, the webinar has received positive feedback, and you can watch the recorded session again.

item.title: New Macao Trainees in Brussels
item.description: A new group of Macanese trainees arrived at SCIC on 11 May, for the second phase of their training programme.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
From left to right: Ms Manuela Sousa Aguiar, Mr Veno Chang, Mr Kaiqi Hu, Ms Tim Ha Ka, Mr Chi Keong Chan, Mr Man Lok Ku, Ms Ian Io, Ms Florika Fink-Hooijer, Ms Lai Seong Sio, Mr François Génisson, Ms Etelvina Rocha Gaspar, Ms Mariangela Barros.


The current training programme is the first of 3 courses contemplated in the recent Protocol signed between SCIC and the SAPF (Public Administration Service of Macau) and in the framework of SCIC's International Cooperation programs.

Similar programmes have been taking place since 2006, in response to a request by the Macanese authorities for high quality interpreter training.  

The objective of this cooperation project is to increase the number of qualified interpreters available to the Macanese authorities, to meet the needs of their bilingual Chinese-Portuguese administration and keep the role of Macao as a bridge between China and the Portuguese speaking countries.

Training in Macao and Brussels is provided by colleagues of the Portuguese unit and focuses on interpretation skills, consolidation of active/passive Portuguese and promoting a better knowledge of Europe.

The first phase of this training programme began on 27 February 2017, in Macao, under the guidance of SCIC trainers. The second phase will be completed on 27 July 2017.

We wish them good luck and an enjoyable stay.

item.title: Stagiaires de Macao à la DG Interprétation
item.description: Dans le cadre du Protocole de coopération avec Macao, un nouveau groupe de stagiaires de Macao a entamé la deuxième partie de sa formation à Bruxelles le 11 mai 2017.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
De gauche à droite: Mme Manuela Sousa Aguiar, M Veno Chang, M Kaiqi Hu, Mme Tim Ha Ka, M Chi Keong Chan, M Man Lok Ku, Mme Ian Io, Mme Florika Fink-Hooijer, Mme Lai Seong Sio, M François Génisson, Mme Etelvina Rocha Gaspar, Mme Mariangela Barros.

Le programme en cours s'insère dans le cadre de la coopération international du SCIC à l'abri d'un nouveau Protocole signé par le SCIC et le SAFP (Services d'Administration et Fonction Publique de Macao).

Des programmes similaires ont déjà été mis en œuvre depuis 2006, suite à une demande des autorités de Macao qui souhaitaient mettre en place une formation d'interprètes de haut niveau.

Son but est d'accroître le nombre d'interprètes qualifiés prêts à travailler dans l'administration bilingue (chinois-portugais) de Macao et ainsi assurer le rôle de Macao en tant que plateforme entre la Chine et les pays lusophones.

Coordonnée et animée par des formateurs de l'unité de langue portugaise, la formation à Macao et à Bruxelles porte essentiellement sur la technique d'interprétation et la consolidation du portugais, mais a l'intention aussi de les familiariser avec la réalité européenne.

Ce programme de formation, dont la première partie s'est déroulée à Macao à partir du 27 février 2017 avec la présence de formateurs du SCIC, se terminera le 27 juillet 2017.

Nous souhaitons à nos stagiaires un franc succès.

item.title: Pedagogical assistance in Buea
item.description: In the framework of the PAMCIT project, Fiona Cabassut from the French booth completed a training mission from 26 March to 4 April. It was her fourth mission in Africa. Here is an illustrated diary of her adventures.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
Buea is the capital of the Southwest Region of Cameroon and has a population of about 90,000.

 


Interpreting with a view:
The University of Buea lies at the foot of Mount Cameroon, which reaches 4090 meters. Because of the altitude, temperatures are milder than down in the plain of Douala. This, however, is a rare shot: most of the time the mountain is shrouded in clouds. Good thing I like heavy, tropical rain!

 

 

 

                             
 

First years students of the Panafrican University. They started just a couple of months ago. Here they are, hard at work, analysing the transcript of a speech given by Doctor Denis Mukwege before the European Parliament when he came to receive the Sakharov Price for Freedom of Thought. The exercise is called "chunking" in the Student's Practise Book by Andrew Gillies: I modified the transcript so that it appears as one big, monolithic, continuous block. The students now have to chunk it up into smaller units every time they think the speaker made a pause or moved on to a new idea. Then they have to choose one key word for each idea. Ultimately, I'll ask a few of them to deliver the same speech, but using only this list of key words. I like this exercise because it helps tremendously. It's a lot easier to work from a written transcript to start with. Students have enough time to reflect and ponder and it's a very good introduction to analysis. I use only transcripts of actual speeches to make sure it's realistic, but also to introduce the students to a more formal way of expressing ideas.

 

It was a sunny day, so it's a bit hard to spot my hieroglyphs on the black board, but it's the continuation of the same class. We've now moved on to the spoken word, but the exercise remains pretty much the same: the students have to analyse in order to identify the ideas and understand the logic. At this stage, we insist a lot on links between each and every idea. I ask the students to do consecutive interpretation without notes in pairs, after which we all come back together to reconstruct the logical sequence. It's easier for them to visualise it on the board, which also gives me an opportunity to illustrate how it could have been taken down in notes.

 

  
 

First years of the Advanced School of Translators and Interpreters (ASTI), the Cameroonian school. Here we are warming up with connectors.
Often students find it difficult to clearly understand the link a speaker has made between one idea and the next, and even more difficult to express it. That's why it never hurts to go over the many different ways in which we articulate thought at the beginning of the course.

 

 

These are the second year students of ASTI and they are just a few months' away from their final exams. A few of them were repeating their final exams, though, and analysis was still a challenge for them. So I proposed an exercise which one of my teachers back in interpreting school called "parking the cars". Closer to home, Roderick Jones called it the salami technique: you take the smallest possible unit of meaning, make a sentence with it and move on to the next. It's a well-known technique which enables interpreters to make sure they can always land on their feet when the going gets tough… The others will be doing advanced consecutive in pairs, so as to get as much practise out of the same speech as possible.

  

 
 

 

And now everybody's going into the booth!
Being able to use recorded videos is a definite bonus, as it gives students an opportunity to work from different speakers, with different accents, paces and idiosyncratic ways of expressing themselves… This, for instance, was a speaker from East Africa and presented a challenge in Cameroon. It also shows students examples of real-life conferences, which is very important as most of the time the exercises we can do in a classroom are somewhat artificial.

 

 

The overhead projector you see here was the unfortunate victim of a short-circuit, so we had to be creative. All the students went into the booths with their own laptop. We positioned a loudspeaker underneath a microphone so that everybody had the same audio and they all looked at their screens for the video. After each interruption, we had to make sure the students were at the exact same minute and second I was… Tedious, but it worked surprisingly well. Equipment is one of the issues that the PAMCIT programme will improve greatly. As well as power outages, hopefully, if the university is able to buy a generator.

item.title: SCIC Relay 129 - Anita Simola
item.description: In the hundred and twenty-ninth instalment of our SCIC Relay series, we meet Anita Simola, our colleague from the Finnish booth.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
Name: Anita Simola
Years at SCIC: 16
Job title: Interpreter coordinator
Unit: SCIC.A.8 (Finnish booth)
Nationality: Finnish
Home town: Lahti, Finland


 

1. What do you like most about working at SCIC?
Being a relay, a channel of thoughts for all these languages spoken in the meetings, I love the sound of all of them, even the ones I don't yet understand. Multilingualism is the essence of our work and the core of the heart of Europe. My heart and soul speak French.

2. What's the strangest question you were ever asked about your job?
"How on earth are you able to think and speak at the same time?!"

3. Do you have a favourite quote?
My grandmother used to say:

"Even before getting out of the bed we have lived through our day. The week is done, the month and sometimes a whole year of activities is all planned in a frenetic fast forward. Like we had forever. We keep forgetting that every breath is a miracle. Be grateful, be present, live your dream. Now!"

4. Which book, movie or person has made the greatest impression on you and why?
The Earthsea cycle by Ursula K. Le Guin. I read the first 3 parts when I was 12 years old. It changed me and the way I see the world. The photo with the sparrowhawk I chose for this interview is inspired by these tales.

5.What is your most treasured possession?
Oh my bouddhas! I can't decide which one I treasure the most. They are more than 25 from different parts of the world. It has been a pleasure to repair, repaint and regild them as most arrived in a poor condition. My friends call my home the "buddha rescue center". But above all I treasure my friends the most.

6. Quelles sont vos prévisions de vacances?
Les vacances, rien de tel pour passer le cap de ses 50 ans! Cette année je n'aurai pas le temps de ruminer, je voyagerai du Mexique au Panama, de l'Inde en Indonésie, des Etats-Unis à Hawaii. Une pensée et un clin d'oeil en passant pour toi mamie!

7. What do you enjoy doing in your spare time?
When not interpreting or learning languages - sanskrit is my latest passion - you will most probably find me on my yoga mat. The second best guess would be training in a boxing ring or then again with paintbrushes and vivid colours in front of a huge canvas.

8. In your opinion, what is the best invention ever?
Time. Although some of us would consider it to be a discovery.

I would like to pass on the relay to: Satu Ylanen-Campbell and Veijo Kruth.

item.title: SCIC Relay 119 - Khalid Bouazza
item.description: In the hundred and ninteenth installment of our SCIC Relay series, we meet Khalid Bouazza, our colleague from the Support to Management and Core Processes, IT Development unit.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
Nom:  Khalid Bouazza
Nombre d'années au SCIC: 2
Titre du poste: Information System Developer
Unité: S3
Nationalité: Belgique
Ville d’origine: Bruxelles (d'origine marocaine)

 

1) Quelles sont vos responsabilités principales au SCIC?
Je fais partie de l'équipe de développement informatique. En ce moment et depuis 2 ans, je m'occupe du développement du nouveau système WebDOR.

2) Que changeriez-vous dans le monde si vous en aviez la possibilité?
Pleins de choses… Mais disons que d'après moi tout part de ceci : si tout le monde se sentait égal aux autres, ça éliminerait beaucoup de fléaux et ça améliorerait le vivre-ensemble. Indirectement, cela éradiquerait les guerres, la famine, la course aux richesses, en gros la bêtise humaine..

3) Quelle est la question la plus étrange que l'on vous ait posée à propos de votre emploi?
Les gens qui n'ont pas une certaine proximité avec des développeurs en informatique ont beaucoup de mal à vraiment comprendre notre métier. J'ai souvent des connaissances qui ont simplement compris que je réparais des ordinateurs… Mais l'anecdote qui m'a le plus marqué est celle d'un rhumatologue chez qui j'avais été pour mon dos. Lorsqu'il me demanda ce que je faisais et que je lui ai répondu (assez génériquement je l'avoue) que j'étais informaticien, sa réplique était "ah, vous portez donc des ordinateurs, parfois lourd peut-être?".  Ça aurait pu arriver à n'importe qui, mais ça venait d'un médecin, qui dans mon esprit à une certaine culture générale. Non, la première chose qu'il a associée à l'informatique c'est de porter des ordinateurs :-)

4) Quel produit ou quel aspect de la vie de votre pays d'origine aimeriez-vous trouver à Bruxelles?
Plusieurs choses. D'abord le soleil ! Parce qu'ici on n'est pas très gâtés en la matière ! Et donc l'ambiance "estivale" que l'on retrouve là-bas en fait. Les activités qui vont avec, les marches nocturnes le long de la plage, les magasins ouverts jusqu’à pas d'heure (car là-bas très peu restent ouvert l'après-midi, c'est l'heure de la sieste, ça aussi c'est bien :-)

5) Quel est votre possession la plus chère?
Ma fille, ça n'a pas de prix!

6) Quels sont vos prévisions de vacances?
2 semaines dans une villa en Espagne, avec 2 couples d'amis (et enfants). Le soleil !

7) Qu'aimez-vous faire durant votre temps libre?
Je suis très famille. Du coup les soirées en week-end, je les consacre à ma famille.  A part ça, je fais beaucoup de fitness (3x/semaine + le dimanche)

8) A votre avis, quelle est la meilleure invention au monde?
En bon geek, je vais répondre le smartphone ! Qui aurait cru qu'avec une toute petite boite dans notre poche on aurait accès à tout ? Bon ça a ses côtés négatifs, parce que par exemple sur une soirée en ami il y aura toujours un moment ou tout le monde jette un œil la dessus et est déconnecté du reste du groupe pour au moins 5 minutes… mais bon son utilité (si vraiment c'est une utilité) première je trouve ça top!

 

J'aimerais passer le SCIC Relay à: Anita Simola

item.title: European Development Days 2017: Mission Accomplished by SCIC
item.description: DG SCIC took part in the European Development Days on 7 and 8 June.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
DG SCIC was at the two day forum on international development to present the international project PAMCIT, the Pan-African Consortium for Conference Interpreting and Translation.

PAMCIT had a stand, where visitors could try their luck at interpreting a speech into a language of their choice (Arabic, French & Swahili to name just a few), as well as talk to PAMCIT graduates, students, trainers, and project leaders. High-profile delegates such as the Togo Minister for Young People and Youth Employment, Ms Victoire Dogbe, European Commission Director General of Development and Cooperation, Mr Stefano Manservisi, our Director General, Ms Florika Fink-Hooijer and even the President of Senegal, Mr Macky Sall (pictured), stopped by and spoke warmly of the project. SCIC also provided simultaneous interpretation in English, French, Spanish and in sign language for the event.

This event has made a real impact for DG SCIC. The PAMCIT project made new contacts with actors of International Development, paved the way for employment opportunities for graduates of PAMCIT programmes, showcased their talent on the world stage, and attracted students who now envisage joining the programme.

Paule Kekeh, desk officer for PAMCIT wanted to give thanks to the team involved - Patricia Mortelmans, Leonid Gutesa, Lucinda Afreixo, Walker Darke, Miklós Mátyássy, Liam Long, Fiona Cabassut, Kate Davies, Anabela Frade, Daniel de Brier, Hediye Kavlak, as well as the PAMCIT permanent coordinator Nina Okagbue, our graduate Jeff Bourema Zerbo and our second year masters student Ousmane Balogoun. 'I am deeply grateful to all for this collective success', she said.

You can view our videos about PAMCIT on SCIC's YouTube channel, including the latest video production by Lucinda Alfreixo.

You can view our social media output on Facebook and Twitter.

item.title: SCIC Relay 136 - Laura Zelča
item.description: In the hundred and thirty-sixth instalment of our SCIC Relay series, we meet Laura Zelča, our colleague from the Latvian Interpretation Unit.
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
Name: Laura Zelča
Years at SCIC: 7
Job Title: Interpreter
Unit: Latvian
Nationality: Latvian
Home town: Riga

 

1) What do you like most about working at SCIC?
Colleagues! There are so many talented, inspiring, fascinating people in SCIC.


2) If you could change anything in the world what would it be? 
I would make teleportation a reality already. 


3) Which product or aspect of life from your native country would you most like to have in Brussels?
The chance to be alone with nature. A long walk along the seaside, when you only encounter a person every hour or so is so relaxing. No people. Mmm. 


4) Which talent would you most like to have?
To make people laugh. Ideally, with me, not just about me. Though any is fine, really. Laughter, together with cat’s purring are my favourite sounds. Ok, wind in pine trees by the seaside is a good sound too. But I don’t have influence on seaside breezes. So, yes, making people laugh.


5) Do you have a favourite quote?
I like this passage from Atonement by Ian McEwan: “There must be some lofty, god-like place from which all people could be judged alike, not pitted against each other, but seen noisily jostling around together in all their glorious imperfection.”
Also, from Winnie-the-Pooh, “Piglet: How do you spell love? Pooh: You don’t spell it, you feel it.”


6) Which book, movie or person has made the greatest impression on you and why?
Stephen Fry’s wealth of knowledge, sense of humour, playfulness with language have entertained and informed me and made me more curious about the world. 


7) What are your holiday plans?
I am excited to combine a mission to Malta with a few days off there. There is a Thailand and Cambodia trip coming up and after that I can’t wait to spend a longer time in my lovely Latvia. 


8) What do you enjoy doing in your spare time?
I play improvisational theatre with the group Impro For Dummies. I also sing in the Brussels Latvian choir. 
I enjoy doodling silly pictures and comic strips. And, of course, travelling, and learning die schöne Deutsche Sprache.

item.title: SCIC-Universities Conference: follow-up
item.description: The twenty-first edition of the SCIC-Universities conference took place on 6 & 7 April 2017 in Brussels, Charlemagne building. Read all about it and relive the conference via webstream!
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
171 representatives from more than 85 different universities in EU Member States, candidate and third countries, International Organisations and other European Institutions, attended the twenty-first edition of SCIC's annual flagship event.

This year, the conference focused on "Building Capacities for a Changing World" and was received positively by all attending and those watching and engaging online, bringing forward some thought-provoking but also some novel and stimulating ideas on interpretation training, academic cooperation and networking.

Various speakers from partner universities and EU institutions, as well as external experts, tackled hot topics related to interpretation and contributed greatly to creating interesting, useful and varied debates on the latest developments in the field of interpretation.
"Interpreters cannot be replaced by computers or robots" said Commissioner Günther H. Oettinger in the inspirational opening address that he delivered on the first day of the event. 

Together with SCIC's Director General Florika Fink-Hooijer he also presented the diplomas to the three winning students of this year's essay contest "Young Interpreters Award".

The programme, winning essays, and other useful material related to the conference are available on the webpage of the event.

Interested to (re)watch the conference? click here for day one, and click here for day 2.

item.title: Task Force "New Technologies – Digital Transformation"
item.description: Staying ahead of the curve in the era of digitalisation
item.infsonewsroom:FullContent:
At our All-Staff-Day in January all colleagues engaged in a lively discussion on how to ensure that DG SCIC as a whole stays "fit for purpose" in a rapidly changing environment. The reports of the five reflection groups - set up in the autumn of last year - provided us with a wealth of recommendations to kick-start an informed discussion, which was continued afterwards at directorates and senior management level.

It became apparent that our DG is absent from the wider policy discussion on digitalisation - including on the delivery of public or linguistic services - which are ongoing in the Commission. The latest reflection paper on "Harnessing Globalisation" adopted by the College for instance states that "we are still in the early phase of the transformation where digitalisation, robots, artificial intelligence… will revolutionise how we produce, work, move and consume…..The jobs that will be created and brought back to Europe will be different from those that moved away years ago. The challenge for Europe will be to innovate in strategic technologies and help workers to gain the right skills to avoid widening the gap in the labour market.”

Digitalisation, automation and artificial intelligence are likely to impact over time the mandate and business model of our DG. It is therefore important for DG SCIC to stay ahead of the curve and influence standard setting in this area, as regards interpretation but also on conferencing and room management.

To respond to this call, DG SCIC Senior Management Board - at its meeting on 8 May 2017 – decided to establish a Task Force on "New Technologies – Digital Transformation".

The key objective of the Task Force will be to enable DG SCIC (in view of its entire portfolio) to stay abreast of technological and policy changes in order for its management to take informed policy decisions and reap the full potential of the digital transformation under way. In this context, the Task-Force will be driven by the following principles:

  • Connecting and networking with other Commission DGs and interinstitutional stakeholders
  • Collecting business intelligence
  • Running pilot projects and initiatives (i.e. have the right to trial new solutions of relevance to DG SCIC's mandate, including the right to fail)
  • Advising SCIC management.

The Terms of Reference of the Task Force are available here. It is important to stress that its mandate is distinct from the one of the Standing Technical Group (GPT) working on matters relevant to interpreters' working conditions, although the Task Force might liaise with the GPT on some specific points.

The Task Force will work under the chairmanship of Marc Berthiaume, Head of Unit in SCIC.S3 and will be composed of members designated by Directorates A, C and S:  

  • Antoinette LEGRAND (Directorate A)
  • Alexander DRECHSEL (Directorate A)
  • Carlos GARCIA VICO (Directorate A)
  • Ramunas CESONIS (Directorate A)
  • Jorge ANDRADE SILVA (alternate member - Directorate A)
  • Fernando LEITAO (Directorate C)
  • Angeles CUALLADO (Directorate C)
  • Jeroen OEY (Directorate S)
  • Sue PHILLIPS (Directorate S).

I wish Marc and colleagues involved a good start in exploring this important domain for DG SCIC and count on them to represent the interest and strengths of our DG in discussions with other services, while also providing the DG SCIC Senior Management Board with informed advice on new technologies and the digital transformation process.


Florika Fink-Hooijer
